Award.AwardTitle: Funding Request for the Organization of a Short Course on Spin Transport Physics and Devices during the 68th Device Research Conference. Held at the Univ. of ND June 21-23

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual merit.
This proposal requests partial funding support to organize a short course on
Spin Transport and Devices during the 68th Device Research Conference. This short course aims
to introduce the device physics community attending DRC to the new science and potential
applications of spin electronics and optoelectronics. It will bring together world experts in spin
science and technology and it will foster student participation.

Broader Impact. The proposed short course on spin transport and devices will provide student
participants with an opportunity to gain exposure the basic physics and potential engineering
applications of spin devices. The timing of this workshop is perfect for this generation of
students to learn how the new science and technology of spin devices is developing. These
lessons will be useful beyond spin electronics, as these students will be able to apply them to
future new materials and technologies that they will encounter during their career. Special effort
will be made to involve female and minority students in the short course by advertisement and
active recruitment. In addition, the conference proceedings will be available online through the
IEEE IEEExplore which will make them accessible world-wide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Now that conventional electronics is reaching its fundamental limits, it is time to identify new approaches for computation and electronics. Spin-based devices are one of the most promising options for this new kind of electronics. Through this project, NSF supported the organization of a Short Course on Spin Transport Physics and Devices during the 68th Device Research Conference. The workshop was held on the campus of the University of Notre Dame, South Bend, IN, on June 20th, 2010, and it had an excellent participation of undergraduate and graduate students, as well as of faculty, postdoctoral fellows, research scientists, and industry participants.

The NSF funding was used to partially cover the organizational expenses of the Short Course, and to reduce the registration fees for graduate and undergraduate students attending it. In addition, it provided partial travel support to 17 outstanding students. These students were nominated by their universities and faculty advisors. The support provided by NSF allowed the student participants to gain exposure to new concepts of spin science and technology. It also provided an excellent opportunity for them to meet other students interested in advanced electronic devices, as well as some of the world leaders in the development of spin based devices.
